question:
What is the primary limitation of the Degree of Network Crosslinking (DNC) parameter in characterizing polyamide membranes?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
The degree of network crosslinking (DNC) is a commonly used structural parameter to depict the polyamide networks formed by trifunctional and bifunctional monomers. The polyamide networks are typically categorized into crosslinking structures and linear structures, wherein the proportion of crosslinking structure is defined as DNC12. Representing the branching degree of polyamide, DNC provides a qualitative depiction of the compactness of polyamide networks. However, it has become increasingly challenging to establish a reliable and consistent correlation between DNC and water permeance or salt rejection in recent desalination researches. This primarily stems from the oversight of the significant number of terminal groups introduced by the emerging regulated methods of interface polymerization. These methods, such as free interfacial polymerization, interlayer construction, control agent addition, and reactive monomer spraying, inhibit the diffusion of amine monomers and accelerate the hydrolysis of TMC, resulting in large residue of carboxyl groups in the polyamide network. On the other hand, conducting interfacial polymerization at low temperatures introduces amino groups into the polyamide network, as evidenced by the positive charge on one side of the polyamide membrane. These terminal groups significantly influence the  ionization behavior and electrical properties of polyamide, ultimately affecting the rejection of high-valence ions. Regrettably, these terminal groups were ignored in the calculation process of DNC, resulting in abnormal DNC values below 0% or exceeding 100%. Moreover, the calculation of DNC usually relies on X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data, which employs the charge shift of the full spectrum, theoretical binding energy (BE), and peak fitting primarily based on the 1s peak of adventitious carbon. This approach, however, is not ideally compatible with carbon-based organic polymer materials with complex chemical environments, which further undermines the credibility of DNC as a reliable parameter for characterizing polyamide networks. On the one hand, the chemical environment of C in polyamide is complex, and the peaks in XPS are very wide. question:
How does increasing PEI concentration affect the membrane's water contact angle?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
The membrane surface with hydrophilic groups has low tendency in membrane fouling. As indicated in Fig. 5, with increasing GA concentration from 0.1 wt% to 0.3 wt% at fixed PEI concentration of 1 wt% in coating solution, the contact angle decreased from 50.2° to 38.9°. This revealed that more GA molecules reacted with PEI resulting in that more hydroxyl groups of gallic acid (GA) were successfully introduced onto the HPAN NF membrane surface and endowed the membrane with good hydrophilicity. In contrast, if increasing PEI concentration from 1 wt% to 2 wt% at fixed GA concentration of 0.1 wt % in coating solution, the contact angle increased from 50.2° to 75.7° owing to that PEI molecules had many hydrophobic vinyl groups. As a result, both hydroxyl group of GA and hydrophobic vinyl groups of PEI  dominated the contact angle of the prepared HPAN NF membrane.

What is the surface mean pore sizes of the microfiltration ceramic tubular membranes used as substrates?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
Microfiltration ceramic tubular membranes were used as the substrates for synthesizing polyamide thin film membranes as they are commercially available at low cost. With high porosity and water permeability, the microfiltration substrates will contribute a low mass transfer resistance to the thin film composite membranes. Fig. 1a shows the SEM image of the cross-section of the tubular membranes. The membranes used in this study had an average inner and outer diameter of 3 and 5 mm, respectively. Fig. 1b is the cross-sectional image near the inner surface of the substrate. It can be seen that the substrate consists of two layers: a support layer with large ceramic particles that provides strong mechanical properties, and a surface layer with smaller particles that provides a smoother surface and a more homogeneous pore size. The ceramic membranes with two pore sizes, 100 and 200 nm (denoted as S-100 and S-200) were used in this study and both substrates had a fairly sharp pore size distribution (Fig. 1c). The mean pore sizes of the substrates S-100 and S-200 were 127 and 195 nm, respectively. The substrates had much larger pore sizes compared to the ceramic substrates used in previous studies for polyamide thin film synthesis. Fig. 1d and e shows the surface morphology of the ceramic substrates, and it was observed that the substrates S-200 had a much porous surface structure compared to the substrates S-100.
label: S-100 was 127 nm and S-200 was 195 nm.

Which of the three membranes will show the lowest foulant–membrane interaction forces in the AFM test and explain why?

The flux profiles of the NF 270, cLBL and LBL-cPP membranes under continuous filtration mode with real municipal wastewater are illustrated in Fig. 8. The decline in permeability was observed for all NF membranes, which could be attributed to the 1) deposition of predominantly rejected inorganic ions and organic molecules on the membrane surface and the 2) formation of cake/biofilm layer originated from the build-up of colloidal particles, soluble microbial products and microorganisms. The periodical cleaning of NF membranes was performed when the permeability dropped to 80% of the initial flux. As seen in Fig. 8, the flux of NF 270 dropped almost linearly from the starting point and required the most frequent cleaning among all membranes. In addition, the flux was not able to recover after each cleaning process indicating irreversible fouling on the membrane surface. For the cLBL membrane, the interval between each cleaning cycle was extended, indicating lower fouling rate and better antifouling ability. As mentioned above, LBL deposition ameliorated the hydrophilicity of the resultant NF membrane, which effectively maximized  the surface hydration and alleviated the foulants adsorption. Hence, the membrane was more easily recovered after regular physical cleaning.
label: LBL-cPP membranes. PDA/PEI coating on the LBL layer enhanced antifouling property.

Describe how MD simulations supported the experimental findings on PIP monomer diffusion in the hydrogel.
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
Multiscale simulations were conducted to study the diffusion of PIP monomers in the nanofibrous Kevlar hydrogel and the process interfacial polymerization on the nanofibrous hydrogel  (simulation details can be found in the ESI in Section 3†). Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations were carried out to calculate the diffusion rate of PIP monomers in the free water and in the nanobrous hydrogel (Fig. 4a and b). The diffusion coefficients of the PIP molecules can be estimated from the slope of the mean square displacement (MSD) curves in Fig. 4c by the Einstein relationship.35 The diffusion rate of PIP monomers in water (6.0 10 10 m2 s 1) agrees well with the experimental results (6.07 10 10 m2 s 1 at 1.46 mol L 1, 298.15 K) in aqueous solution, which conrms the accuracy of our MD simulations. The diffusion rate of PIP monomers in the hydrogel is 4.3 10 10 m2 s 1, 28.3% lower than that in the water, conrming our hypothesis in the explanation of the ultrahigh water permeability of hydrogel-TFC membranes in the previous section. The relatively low PIP diffusion rate in the nanobrous Kevlar hydrogel is mainly attributed to the hydrogen bonding interactions between the PIP monomers and the Kevlar networks; this also affects the interfacial polymerization. Therefore, dissipative particle dynamics (DPD) simulations were carried out to investigate the interfacial polymerization on the nanobrous hydrogel. The snapshots of the initial simulation system before the interfacial polymerization process, as well as the equilibrium state of the system aer the interfacial polymerization process are presented in Fig. 5. As shown in Fig. 5a and c, PIP monomers are well dispersed in water and the hydrogel before interfacial polymerization. Aer a simulation of 500 000 steps to reach the equilibrium state of the system, all the PIP monomers moved to the interface of free n-hexane and free water in the free water/n-hexane system (Fig. 5b). In contrast, there were still many PIP monomers left in the hydrogel without moving to the interface in the Kevlar hydrogel/ n-hexane system (Fig. 5d), indicating a lower diffusion rate of PIP monomers in the hydrogel. More specically, the PIP monomers remaining in the hydrogel preferentially attached on the Kevlar molecules, which conrmed the hydrogen bonding interactions between the PIP monomers and the Kevlar network. In addition, compared to the thin selective layer in Fig. 5b, the active layer formed in the hydrogel system is thought to be thinner than that in the water system, due to the strong interaction between PIP and the Kevlar network.

question:
What was the effect of pH on BSA fouling at the isoelectric point (pH 4.7)?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
Bovine serum albumin (BSA) is a protein commonly used to characterize the fouling propensity of membranes. The Stokes  radius of BSA, 3.5 nm,55 is larger than the pore diameter of the copolymer membranes developed here, 3.4 ± 0.4 nm. As such, pore blockage and the formation of a cake layer on the top surface of the membrane are expected to be the primary mechanisms of fouling. These mechanisms will be driven by the attractive interactions between the foulants and the surface of the membrane. For the charge-functionalized membranes discussed here, the electrostatic interactions between BSA dissolved in solution and the membrane surface are critical to determining the magnitude of these interactions. One method for modulating these interactions is to examine the fouling profiles for solutions of varying pH. In particular, BSA has an  isoelectric point at pH 4.7−4.9.56 At this pH value, the protein has an equal balance of positive and negative charges, such that it is overall neutral. Below and above this pH value, the BSA  molecules are positively and negatively charged, respectively. Based on this prior characterization, 0.5 g L−1 BSA, 1 mM NaCl solutions adjusted to pH 3 or pH 4.7 were used for the initial series of fouling experiments. The pH 3 solution was chosen to maximize the electrostatic attraction between the positively charged foulant and the negatively charged membranes. The pH 4.7 solution was examined because it coincides with the isoelectric point of BSA.
label: Enhanced fouling due to reduced electrostatic repulsion.

question:
Please generate a title for this article based on the abstract.
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
Considering growing efforts to understand and improve the solute-specific selectivity of nanofiltration (NF) membranes, we explored the ion-specific effects that govern the charge and performance of a loose polyamide NF membrane that is commonly used for solute-solute separations. Specifically, we systematically evaluated the zeta potential of the membrane under different conditions of pH, salinity, and ionic composition, and correlated the obtained data with membrane performance tested under similar conditions. Our results identify the pKa of both carboxylic and amine groups bonded to the membrane surface and suggest that the highly polarizable chloride anions in the solution adsorb to the polyamide, increasing its negative charge. We also show that monovalent cations of different “stickiness” can neutralize the negative membrane charge to different extents due to their varying tendency to sorb to the polymer matrix or screen the fixed carboxyl groups on the membrane surface. Notably, our correlation between zeta potential measurements and permeability experiments indicates the substantial contribution of solution ions to Donnan exclusion in NF membranes.
label: Effect of solution ions on the charge and performance of nanofiltration membranes

What kind of ions will be more adsorbed by the membrane?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
The current study systematically investigates the Zeta Potential (ZP) and ion permeability of a polyamide NF membrane under a wide range of pH values, ionic compositions, and ionic strength to explore how solution ions affect the charge and performance of the membrane. Our results imply that the membrane-solution interactions are ion-specific, where “stickier” weakly hydrated ions (e.g., Cs+) can more easily shed their hydration shell to attach to the membrane backbone and affect its charge, compared to less “sticky” strongly hydrated ions (e.g., Li+). Additionally, we show that chlorides, which have greater polarizability than the investigated cations, can adsorb to uncharged membrane segments, enhancing the Donnan exclusion of solution anions. Overall, our work clarifies existing discrepancies in ZP studies and demonstrates the contribution of adsorbed solution ions to the charge and performance of NF membranes by correlating between ZP, the ionization behavior of the fixed groups, and ion rejection and permeability.
label: Ions with lower hydration enthalpy and higher polarizability

question:
What does the following context mainly explain?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
Our results show a clear inverse correlation between the parameters; that is, salt permeability is reduced with the increase in |ζ|, which implies that ZP is a reasonable indicator for Donnan exclusion. For instance, at pH 4.0 and I = 1 mM, the |ζ| is relatively low due to weak membrane charge with the accompanying reduced Donnan effects, which results in relatively high ion permeability (Fig. 4b). At pH 7.5 and high ionic strength, the |ζ| is greater and consequently ion permeability is reduced. The main reason for the lower permeability under these conditions is schematically explained in Fig. 4c, showing higher membrane charge, which is partly neutralized by the ions. At pH 7.5 and low ionic strength (Fig. 4d), there is limited charge screening, therefore many membrane charges generate strong Donnan effects resulting in very low permeability. The ZP results may also imply subtle differences in Donnan exclusion experienced by Li+ and Cs+, as reflected by the good correlation between the ratios of LiCl and CsCl ζ (rζ 1⁄4 ζLiCl=ζCsCl) and Ps (rP 1⁄4 PsðLiClÞ=PsðCsClÞ). Notably, the largest rζ was obtained at pH 7.5 and 1 mM, where the negative membrane charge is high (Fig. 1a, c) and charge screening is minor (Fig. 4d), leading to noticeable differences in Cs+ and Li+ permeabilities (rP = 0.74). It is stressed that we tested the match between ZP and Donnan exclusion only for pH ≤ 7.5, where the fixed membrane charge is solely influenced by protonation of carboxyl groups (Eq. (1)), while the amine groups are positively charged throughout the pH range. Thus, in the tested conditions, ZP is directly related to the overall number of charged fixed groups. On the other hand, at pH > 7.5, the increase in |ζ| with pH is the outcome of the protonation of  charged amine groups (i.e., Eq. (2)), resulting in a decrease in overall number of charged groups, but an increase in the overall negative charge. Lastly, we considered the potential effect of the carbonate system and water ions on the pH near the membrane wall. Based on the pKa values, the concentrations of the various species (Supplementary Table 3), and the expected permeability of the species, we computed the potential effect on the pH (e.g., Supplementary Fig. 2). These calculations showed the minor effect of the carbonate system and water ions on our results.
label: Correlation between membrane zeta potential and ion permeability

Moreover, the pure water permeability can reach 23 LMH/bar.

What is the principle of ultrasonic reflectometry for monitoring membrane systems?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
The ultrasonic reflectometry for monitoring membrane systems is based on the reflection characteristics of ultrasonic waves when they propagate through different media. When ultrasonic waves encounter the interfaces of different media in the membrane system (such as the interface between fresh feed and the fouling layer), part of the energy is reflected to form reflected waves. By measuring the time difference (such as the time difference dT between the reflected waves of different interfaces) and combining it with the propagation speed C of ultrasonic waves in the medium, the thickness change dS of the fouling layer can be determined using the formula dS = 0.5C×dT, thus achieving real - time monitoring of membrane fouling.
label: The reflection characteristics of ultrasonic wave are different when it propagates in different media.

1. **Ultrasonic Wave Propagation:** The method relies on sending ultrasonic waves through the membrane system.

2. **Reflection at Interfaces:** When these waves encounter interfaces between different materials within the system (e.g., the interface between the feed solution and a fouling layer that has formed on the membrane), a portion of the wave's energy is reflected back.

3. **Measuring Time Difference:** The key is to measure the time it takes for the reflected waves from different interfaces to return to the sensor. For example, the time difference (dT) between the wave reflected from the feed/fouling interface and the wave reflected from the fouling/membrane interface is crucial.

4. **Calculating Thickness Change:** Knowing the speed of sound (C) in the medium (presumably the feed solution or the fouling layer, depending on which layer's thickness is being measured) and the time difference (dT), the change in thickness (dS) of the fouling layer can be calculated using the formula dS = 0.5 * C * dT. The factor of 0.5 accounts for the fact that the wave travels to the interface and back.

5. **Real-time Monitoring:** By continuously measuring the time differences and calculating the thickness, the method allows for real-time monitoring of membrane fouling.

In summary, ultrasonic reflectometry uses the reflection of ultrasonic waves at interfaces within the membrane system to determine the thickness of fouling layers by measuring the time it takes for the reflected waves to return.

question:
How does the water permeability of the mixed-dimensional membrane compare to conventional flat 2D membranes?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
We evaluated the water purification performance of mixed-dimensional polyamide membranes and compared it with flat membrane and state of the art NF membranes. As presented in Table 1, the mixed-dimensional polyamide membranes present at least equivalent salt rejection performance to flat membrane and the observed selectivity follows the order Na2SO4 > MgSO4 > MgCl2 > CaCl2 > NaCl, indicating a negatively charged NF membrane, as confirmed by zeta potential analysis (Supplementary Fig. 22). Significantly, the mixed-dimensional polyamide membranes showed a water permeability as high as ~30.0 l m−2 h−1 bar−1, which is at least four times higher than that of the flat membrane. More importantly, the separation performance of mixed-dimensional polyamide membranes surpassed the permeance-selectivity upper-bound line of conventional NF membranes (Fig. 5a).
label: 4 times higher

question:
How does the presence of terminal carboxyl and amino groups affect the performance of polyamide membranes?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
In contrast, when HABD is used to describe the crosslinked networks of polyamide, we observe a clear correlation between HABD and the performance of reverse osmosis polyamide membranes. Fig. 3C illustrates an overall improvement of NaCl rejection with the increase of HABD. The Spearman correlation coefficient for this relationship is 0.649, much larger than that of DNC. This indicates a strong positive correlation between HABD and NaCl rejection. Likewise, a discernible trend of decreasing water permeance and NaCl permeability coefficient is visible with the increase of HABD (Fig. 3D and Supplementary Fig. 10). Thanks to the comprehensive analysis of the polyamide structure, the calculated HABD consistently holds physical significance regardless of the proportion of terminal groups. The increase of terminal groups only decreases the value of HABD but will not cause it to become negative. This ensures that HABD can work for loose polyamides with rich terminal groups. Furthermore, HABD more accurately describes the correlations between crosslinked networks and performance. The closer the value of HABD is to 9.3 mmol g-1, the fewer carboxyl and amino groups are present in polyamide, indicating a higher conversion to amide bonds during interfacial polymerization. Crosslinked polyamide membranes with higher HABD thus exhibit  reduced free volume and pore size resulting in higher NaCl rejection and lower water permeance. Our analysis then extends to PIP-TMC type nanofiltration membranes. In this case, the correlation between crosslinked networks and nanofiltration performance becomes more challenging due to the contribution of both pore size and charge properties of polyamide membranes. A denser network provides a higher blocking ability to salt ions owing to the size exclusion effect, while the presence of abundant charge on the membrane surface can also block high-valent salt ions through the Donnan effect. Most PIP-TMC polyamide membranes possess a substantial number of hydrolyzed TMC terminal structures and exhibit negative charges, exacerbating the difficulty to establish the correlation between crosslinked networks and nanofiltration performance. Therefore, it is crucial to conduct a comprehensive analysis of the structure of PIP-TMC polyamide to gain a better understanding of its nanofiltration behavior.
label: This enhances water permeance but may decrease salt rejection unless compensated by charge effects.

As the amide bond density decreases and the number of terminal groups increases in the crosslinked network, PIP-TMC polyamide membrane exhibits higher water permeance. However, the change in Na2SO4 rejection is not significantly affected by the variation in HABD. This observation can be explained by the presence of rich charges on the membrane surface, which blocks high-valent salt ions through the Donnan effect as mentioned. To quantify terminal groups and analyze their ionization behavior, we have introduced two analogous parameters, namely the harmonic carboxyl density (HCD) and the harmonic amino density (HAD). These parameters, reflecting the contents of carboxyl and amino groups per mass of polyamide, are essential in accurately representing the surface charge of polyamides (Section 4 in Supplementary Information). It was demonstrated that PIP-TMC polyamide with higher HCD exhibits a stronger negative charge and higher Na2SO4 rejection (Supplementary Table 9, Supplementary Figs. 17 and 18). Nonetheless, the rejection of nanofiltration membranes is contributed by two factors: the screening of pores brought by polyamide networks and the Donnan effect of surface charge. Therefore, it is challenging to establish reliable structure-activity relationships by isolating these two factors. question:
How does the surface charge of the polyamide nanofilm affect salt rejection?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
Figure 4B illustrates the salt rejection capacity of the polyamide composite membranes (Fig. S14). On the one hand, the membranes show higher rejection to divalent anions (i.e., SO42−)  than monovalent anions (i.e., Cl−). Typically, the rejection to Na2SO4 is 95.6% and 96.6% for the membranes with polyamide  nanofilms of 3.8 and 5.8 nm, respectively. On the other hand, the negatively charged surface contributes to the better rejection to divalent anions than divalent cations [44]. As a result, the salt rejection performance of membranes exhibits a sequence of Na2SO4 > MgSO4 > MgCl2 > CaCl2 > NaCl. Interestingly,  the rejection to Na2SO4 (>95.6%) is much higher than that to NaCl (<34.0%) owing to the stronger electrostatic repulsion  and the larger hydrated ion radius of SO2−  4 (0.38 nm) in contrast  to Cl− (0.33 nm) [45], demonstrating excellent separation ratio between monovalent and divalent ions. The NaCl/Na2SO4 selectivity reaches 21.0 and 23.6 for the composite membranes with nanofilms of 3.8 and 5.8 nm (Fig. 4C). Furthermore, a relatively high rejection to Na2SO4 (>90%) can be maintained under a  wide range of operating pressure from 2 to 8 bar (Fig. S15). On the one hand, the polyamide composite membranes exhibit  excellent water permeance of about 50 l/m2·h·bar and high Na2SO4 rejection of about 95% under a low pressure of 2 bar,  indicating their great potential in low-pressure nanofiltration. On the other hand, the membranes show decent separation  performance with a high Na2SO4 rejection of above 90% even  under high pressure of 8 bar, demonstrating their good mechanical strength during nanofiltration. The robust structure can be ascribed to the high Young's modulus of polyamide nanofilms and the high binding strength between the nanofilm and substrate.
label: The negatively charged surface repels divalent anions more effectively than monovalent ions, leading to higher rejection of Na2SO4.

question:
What was the optimal cross-linking temperature for the prepared loose NF membrane?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
The chemistry property of the thin selective layer and its preparation condition had a decisive effect on separation performance of prepared composite NF membrane [37,38]. Firstly, the cross-linking temperature was studied at fixed concentration for gallic acid (0.1 wt%) and PEI (1 wt%) in coating solutions and cross-linking time of 30 min and the corresponding results were given in the Fig. 8. The permeate fluxes were sharply decreased from 50 L/m2·h to 10 L/m2·h (for Gongo red) and from 45 L/m2·h to 9.2 L/m2·h (for Methyl blue) while rejection ratios of Gongo red and Methyl blue increased slightly. This proved that skin layer formed by coating modified PEI became denser with increasing the temperature from 45 °C to 75 °C. Therefore, the cross-linking temperature was an important factor influening on  separation performance of the prepared loose NF membrane. Fig. 9(a) presented the effect of gallic acid concentration on the permeation performance of the prepared loose NF membrane at fixed 1 wt% PEI concentration in coating solution under TMP of 0.2 MPa and cross-linking temperature of 45 °C. For 0.1 wt% gallic acid, membrane permeate flux reached up to 51 L/m2· h. However, the further increasing gallic acid concentration from 0.1 wt% to 0.3 wt % would cause the decline in permeate flux, which was decresed from 51 L/m2·h to 29 L/m2·h. This could be explained by sheets polymers surface morphology (Fig. 7). The additon of small amount gallic acid in coating solution could make the selective layer become relatively loose and enhanced membrane permeate flux. Meanwhile, the similar variation trend of permeate flux was also observed with increased PEI concentration at fixed GA concentration of 0.1 wt% in coating solution. As shown in Fig. 9(b), the membrane permeate flux decreased from 51 L/m2·h to 24.5 L/m2·h owing to the fact that the skin layer became denser with increasing PEI concentration and the hydrophlicity of the membrane decreased with increasing PEI concentration.

How will the pure water permeation change if we increase the number of LBL layers? How about shorten crosslinking time?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
As discussed in Section 3.2, the coating of PDA/PEI increased the thickness of selective layer, thereby enhancing the hydraulic resistance through the membrane to both water and salt. In addition, the dual covalent reactions of PDA with PEI and polyelectrolytes in the LBL layer tightened the selective layer structure of the NF membrane, which induced decreased permeability. On a different note, the pure water permeability can be further improved by reducing the thickness of the substrate, increasing the ionic strength (NaCl concentration) of the polyelectrolyte solution, reducing the number of LBL layers, and controlling the crosslinking reaction. A systematic investigation of these parameters will be a focus in our future studies. Despite this, an obvious elevation in all salt rejections was witnessed for the PDA/PEI modified LBL membrane as compared to the LBL membrane (Fig. 6 (B) and Table A1). Particularly, the PDA/PEI coating conferred a fairly high Na2SO4 rejection to the LBL membrane; the rejection improved from 37.4% to 57.8% (Table A1). Such a higher rejection generally benefits from the size exclusion enabled by a denser selectivity layer. Nevertheless, this improvement comes at the sacrifice of pure water permeability. In the case of the commercial NF 270 membrane, the ‘loose’ and negatively charged nature was revealed as an evidence by the higher rejection against Na2SO4 and lower rejection for MgCl2 (Fig. 6(B)). As already been attested by previously study, such an observation suggested that the Donnan exclusion theory played a major role [17]. On the other hand, the salt rejection test suggested that the LBL-cPP NF membrane reached the 90% rejection for divalent  cations and about 20% rejection for monovalent cations, while maintaining the order of MgCl2 > MgSO4 > Na2SO4 > NaCl. This result was reasonable for positively charged NF membrane and corroborated the benefits of a relatively dense selectivity layer brought about by the co-deposition of PDA/PEI. Therefore, it can be concluded that similar results on MgSO4 rejection between the NF 270 and LBL-cPP membranes were due to different dominant rejection mechanisms.

question:
Why test the performance stability of LBL-cPP NF membrane?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
The chemical stability of membrane plays a crucial role in practical applications due to the need for regular chemical cleaning. The covalent polymerization and non-covalent self-assembly synergistically induce the formation of PDA coatings, whereas the non-covalent parts are unstable under harsh conditions. It is well known that the increase of crosslinked structure in coating layer by oxidization will enhance the coating stability [49]. CuSO4/H2O2-triggered PDA/PEI codeposition process creates more covalent parts and crosslinked sites that will be further strengthened by the interactions with the LBL layer to improve coating stability. In this study, the stability of the cLBL and  LBL-cPP NF membranes was tested under different treatment conditions. All the membranes showed a stable permeability and MgCl2 rejection after continuous operation of 50 h with DI water (Fig. A4(A)). Similarly, the permeability and MgCl2 rejection of the cLBL and LBLcPP membranes experienced little change after the treatment of an acidic solution at pH 4 (Fig. A4(B)), indicating good performance stability under acidic environment. However, a remarkable increase for permeability was observed for the cLBL membrane after alkaline treatment (Fig. 7). This demonstrated that the LBL layer was irreversibly swelled due to deionization of amine groups on the PAH polymer chains under strong alkaline condition [19]. Accordingly, the MgCl2 rejection of treated the cLBL membrane dropped by 20% after three alkaline treatment cycles. In contrast, the rejection loss was negligible for the LBL-cPP membrane, which was due to the covalent crosslinking of PDA/PEI on the LBL layer.
label: Regular chemical cleaning is required during actual testing.

To assess the membrane separation performance, we further measured the rejection of a set of neutral hydrophilic probes (ethylene glycol, diethylene glycol, and pentaerythritol), an inorganic micropollutant (boron), and organic micropollutants (propylparaben, norfloxacin, and ofloxacin). The rejections of ethylene glycol, diethylene glycol, and pentaerythritol (dosed at 200 ppm each in the feed solution) were measured at 20 bar following similar procedures as the NaCl rejection measurement. Total organic carbon (TOC, Aurora 1030, OI Analytical, College Station, TX) was used to analyze the concentration of ethylene glycol, diethylene glycol, and pentaerythritol in the feed and permeate samples. The determination of boron rejection (5 ppm, at pH 6) was similarly conducted in which an inductive coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Optima 8 × 00, PerkinElmer) was used to analyze  the boron concentration.38 The rejection of organic micropollutants (propylparaben, norfloxacin, and ofloxacin) was also evaluated. Following the membrane precompaction by DI water, a 1 mL stock solution (1 g/L) of each compound was spiked into 5 L of feed solution to form a concentration of 200 μg/L. The filtration process was then continued for another 12 h. Subsequently, samples from the feed solution and permeate were collected for further detection of these compounds using an UPLC-MS/MS  system.39 The LC separation was implented on an Agilent 1290 system (Santa Clara, CA) using an C18 column (Eclipse Plus, Agilent, 2.1 × 50 mm, 1.8 μm particle size), and the MS/ MS quantification was achieved using an API3200 mass detector (AB Sciex, MA).

question:
How does the hydrogel-TFC membrane achieve higher permeability compared to conventional PA membranes?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
A nanofibrous Kevlar hydrogel was applied as the substrate membrane to support the thin active PA layer during interfacial polymerization. The nanobrous hydrogel was prepared via phase inversion by immersing the Kevlar/DMSO dope solution (2 wt%, Fig. S1†) in a water bath. The obtained Kevlar hydrogel is transparent and so (Fig. 1a), comprising three-dimensional (3D) nanobrous networks (Fig. 1c and S2†) and is signicantly different from conventional polymeric membranes (Fig. S3†) in morphology and structure. Besides, the nanobrous hydrogel has a water content of 96.5 wt% which is much higher than the conventional support membrane. Such a high water uptake makes it similar to the free water phase in synthesizing a freestanding PA membrane. Therefore, the hydrogel can be applied as the aqueous phase in interfacial polymerization to enable a homogeneous polymerization. To introduce PIP monomers into the nanobrous hydrogel, PIP monomers was dissolved in the water bath which is used for the phase inversion (Fig. S6a and b†). In this case, the PIP monomers are preloaded in the nanobrous hydrogel during its formation. Then, the interfacial polymerization was initiated by pouring trimesoyl chloride (TMC)/hexane solution on the porous bottom surface (Fig. S2c†) rather than the dense top surface (Fig. S2d†) of the PIP preloaded hydrogel (Fig. 1b). Aer interfacial polymerization, crosslinked and defect-free PA selective nanolayers with a thickness down to 15.5 nm (Fig. 1d) were obtained. The hydrophilic (Fig. S7,† water contact angle: 54 ) selective PA layer is rmly attached to, even fused to, the surface of the nanobrous hydrogel (Fig. 1e), indicating a robust interaction between the selective layer and the nanobrous hydrogel, and thus the relatively high stability of the TFC membranes. This tight integration of the PA selective layer and the Kevlar hydrogel is mainly due to the high compatibility between these two polymers resulting from the presence of the same chemical groups and their similar chemical composition (Fig. 1f). In addition, the surface of the hydrogel-TFC membrane is entirely smooth with a nanoscale roughness of nearly 8 nm (Fig. 1g). This feature differs from other reported highly permeable membranes with rough crumpled structures or Turning structures, probably endowing the resulting membranes with a lower fouling during desalination compared with these rough membranes. Most importantly, unlike conventional interfacial polymerization involving two stepwise solution immersion processes, only one simple TMC solution immersion was applied to initiate the interfacial polymerization because PIP monomers were preloaded in the hydrogel. This modified interfacial polymerization process simplies the overall membrane synthesis process. Therefore, large pieces of hydrogel-TFC membranes (Fig. 1h) were readily prepared in the lab. This method is also promising to be directly integrated into a commercial membrane production line for scaling up.

The real glucose rejections with a concentration of 10 mg L 1 by VNF1 and VNF2 were shown in Fig. S1. The pore sizes of VNF1 and VNF2 increased with temperature enhancement (Fig. 3a). It was reported that the pore size of NF 270 increased from 0.39 nm to 0.44 nm as the temperature varied from 20 to 40 �C [16]. In this study, the pore sizes of VNF1 and VNF2 increased from 0.48 and 0.46 nm at 5 �C to 0.56 and 0.51 nm at 25 �C (Fig. 3a), respectively. For example, the pure water permeabilities of VNF1 and VNF2 were 2.88 �  10 11 and 2.41 � 10 11 m s 1 Pa 1 at 25 �C, which were 1.71 and 1.99 times higher than those at 5 �C, respectively. *   **Enhanced Osmotic Pressure Effect:** Concentration polarization exacerbates the osmotic pressure effect described above, further hindering water permeation.
*   **Fouling:** High ion concentrations can also contribute to scaling and fouling on the membrane surface, which physically blocks pores and reduces permeability.

**3. Membrane Properties and Ion-Membrane Interactions:**

*   **Charge Effects:** NF membranes are often charged (typically negatively charged). The presence of ions in the feed water can influence the membrane's surface charge and its interaction with other ions.
*   **Swelling/Compaction:** High ionic strength solutions can affect the swelling or compaction of the membrane polymer matrix. This can alter the pore size and structure of the membrane, influencing water permeability. For example, divalent cations can crosslink with the membrane functional groups, leading to membrane compaction and reduced water permeability.
*   **Donnan Effect:** The Donnan effect describes the unequal distribution of ions between the membrane and the external solution due to the presence of fixed charges on the membrane. This can influence the local ion concentrations within the membrane and affect water transport.

*   Increased osmotic pressure opposing water flow.
*   Concentration polarization amplifying the osmotic pressure effect.
*   Potential for scaling and fouling.
*   Alterations in membrane structure (swelling/compaction) due to ion-membrane interactions.

The most widely used model for mass transport is the solution-diffusion model, which assumes that water and solute species transport independently, first by dissolving or partitioning into the PA layer, followed by diffusion across the layer based on their respective concentration gradients, and finally partitioning out of the layer into the permeate. The solution-diffusion model is convenient because it enables the transport characteristics of a TFC-PA membrane to be described with two parameters: the water permeability coefficient and the solute permeability coefficient. Another widely used approach is the pore flow model, or Donnan-steric-pore model with dielectric exclusion (DSPM-DE). The DSPM-DE considers water and ion transport through tortuous cylindrical pores with charge. It can account for steric, Donnan and dielectric exclusions and hindered transport of solutes within pores129 (Fig. 5e). Although the DSPM-DE has many simplifying assumptions and controversialmechanisms, such as including dielectric exclusion, it can provide mechanistic insights about how the change in membrane properties —for instance, pore size and charge density — affects membrane separation performance, in a way not achievable with more phenomenological models. For example, pore size is not used as a parameter in the solution-diffusion, SDEM or solution-friction model.
label: DSPM-DE incorporates pore size, charge, and dielectric exclusion, whereas solution-diffusion focuses on partition and diffusion

*   Furthermore, divalent ions might interact more strongly with the polymer matrix, hindering their diffusion through the membrane.

*   **Potentially larger hydrated size leading to increased steric hindrance.**
*   **Lower affinity for the membrane material and hindered diffusion (as reflected in the solution-diffusion model's solute permeability coefficient).**

question:
What is the critical condition for the formation of Turing structures?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
Turing structures typically emerge in reactiondiffusion processes far from thermodynamic equilibrium, in which the diffusion coefficient of the inhibitor must be larger than that of the activator, resulting in the “local activation and lateral inhibition” phenomenon (Fig. 1B) that underlies diffusion-driven instability. However, this condition is not easily satisfied in homogeneous solutions, for most chemical reactions involve small molecules with similar or inappropriately differing diffusion coefficients. In the classic Turing systems, two main approaches have been developed to selectively control the effective diffusion coefficients of reactants: (i) Introduce a macromolecule that reversibly binds the activator, like starch or polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) in the CIMA reaction, and (ii) use a heterogeneous finely dispersed multiphase reaction system in which the activator resides in a low-mobility phase, such as when polar BZ reagents are confined within nanosized aqueous droplets.
label: The inhibitor must have a higher diffusion coefficient than the activator.

1.  **Reaction-Diffusion System:** Turing structures arise in reaction-diffusion systems. This means there are at least two components that react with each other and also diffuse through the medium.

2.  **Far from Thermodynamic Equilibrium:** The system must be far from thermodynamic equilibrium. This is a general requirement for self-organized pattern formation.

3.  **Diffusion-Driven Instability:** The core mechanism is diffusion-driven instability. This means that diffusion, counterintuitively, drives the formation of spatial patterns rather than homogenizing the system.

4.  **Local Activation and Lateral Inhibition:** This is the key concept underlying diffusion-driven instability. One component acts as an "activator," promoting its own production and/or the production of the other component. Please generate a title for this article based on the abstract.
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
Nanofiltration (NF) membranes play a critical role in separation processes, necessitating an in-depth understanding of their selective mechanisms. Existing NF models predominantly include steric and Donnan mechanisms as primary mechanisms. However, these models often fail in elucidating the NF selectivity between ions of similar dimensions and the same valence. To address this gap, an innovative methodology was proposed to unravel new selective mechanisms by quantifying the nominal dielectric effect isolated from steric and Donnan exclusion through fitted pore dielectric constants by regression analysis. We demonstrated that the nominal dielectric effect encompassed unidentified selective mechanisms of significant relevance by establishing the correlation between the fitted pore dielectric constants and these hindrance factors. Our findings revealed that dehydration-induced ion−membrane interaction, rather than ion dehydration, played a pivotal role in ion partitioning within NF membranes. This interaction was closely linked to the nondeformable fraction of hydrated ions. Further delineation of the dielectric effect showed that favorable interactions between ions and membrane functional groups contributed to entropy-driven selectivity, which is a key factor in explaining ion selectivity differences between ions sharing the same size and valence. This study deepens our understanding of NF selectivity and sheds light on the design of highly selective membranes for water and wastewater treatment.
label: The Hidden Role of the Dielectric Effect in Nanofiltration: A Novel Perspective to Unravel New Ion Separation Mechanisms

What is the main shortcoming of existing NF models in explaining ion selectivity?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
The widely accepted Donnan steric pore model (DSPM)  was developed in 1997 incorporating steric and Donnan exclusion as key mechanisms to explain ion transport through NF membranes. In the early 2000s, the concept of dielectric exclusion was introduced to account for the energy barrier caused by the dielectric constant difference between the bulk solution and the membrane pore. Dielectric exclusion, attributed to the “image force” effect and the Born dielectric effect, was subsequently integrated into the steric, electric, and dielectric exclusion (SEDE) model, enhancing its accuracy. Further studies have revealed that the strength of dielectric exclusion is affected by various factors such as pore geometry, membrane material, and solution  properties, making it challenging to accurately quantify. Numerous studies have attempted to quantify dielectric exclusion, with several comprehensive reviews available in the literature. These studies demonstrate the critical role of dielectric exclusion in membrane selectivity. However, existing models often rely on semiempirical models such as the Bowen model to calculate the membrane permittivity. While mathematically convenient, this approach oversimplifies the system, which may not be compatible with the basic assumptions of NF models. An alternative method involves fitting experimental data to the NF model. The resulting value can then be used as a known parameter for subsequent model predictions, which potentially offers a more accurate representation of the complex interactions within NF membranes.
label: Can't explain the selectivity between ions of similar size and charge. Difficult to quantify dielectric constant.

How does the dielectric constant difference between the bulk solution and the membrane pore affect ion transport?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
As the ion enters a nanopore, the difference in dielectric constant inside and outside the pore necessitates the ion entry to overcome a solvation energy barrier. The hindrance caused by the difference in dielectric constant is known as dielectric exclusion, a fundamental mechanism long considered in NF and strongly associated with the pore size. Recent studies have shown that the use of ion cavity radius over Stokes radius could enable  more precise dielectric exclusion calculations. Consequently, the ion cavity radius is employed in this study for the quantification of dielectric exclusion.
label: It creates an energy barrier

prediction_rationale:
Okay, let's break down how the dielectric constant difference between the bulk solution and the membrane pore affects ion transport, based on the provided context:

1.  **Dielectric Constant Difference:** The core issue is that the dielectric constant (a measure of a material's ability to reduce the electric field) is different inside the membrane pore compared to the bulk solution outside the membrane. Typically, the pore has a lower dielectric constant than the aqueous solution.

2.  **Solvation Energy Barrier:** When an ion attempts to enter the nanopore from the bulk solution, it encounters a change in its dielectric environment. Ions in solution are solvated, meaning they are surrounded by solvent molecules (usually water) that stabilize the ion's charge. Because the dielectric constant inside the pore is lower, the ion is less stabilized (less effectively solvated) within the pore compared to the bulk solution. This difference in solvation creates a solvation energy barrier that the ion must overcome to enter the pore.

3.  **Dielectric Exclusion:** This hindrance to ion entry due to the dielectric constant difference and the resulting solvation energy barrier is called dielectric exclusion. It's a fundamental mechanism in nanofiltration (NF).

4.  **Pore Size Dependence:** Dielectric exclusion is strongly associated with the pore size of the membrane. Smaller pores exacerbate the effect because the ion has to shed more of its solvation shell to enter the confined space, further increasing the energy barrier.

5.  **Ion Cavity Radius:** The context mentions that using the ion cavity radius (the effective size of the ion including its tightly bound solvent molecules) instead of the Stokes radius (hydrodynamic radius) allows for more accurate calculations of dielectric exclusion. This is because the cavity radius better represents the actual volume occupied by the ion and its immediate solvation shell, which is relevant to the dielectric environment it experiences.

In summary, the dielectric constant difference between the bulk solution and the membrane pore creates a solvation energy barrier that hinders ion entry. This phenomenon, known as dielectric exclusion, is influenced by pore size and can be more accurately quantified using the ion cavity radius.

question:
Please generate a title for this article based on the abstract.
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
Interfacial polymerization (IP) provides a versatile platform for fabricating defect-free functional nanofilms for various applications, including molecular separation, energy, electronics, and biomedical materials. Unfortunately, coupled with complex natural instability phenomena, the IP mechanism and key parameters underlying the structural evolution of nanofilms, especially in the presence of surfactants as an interface regulator, remain puzzling. Here, we interfacially assembled polymer nanofilm membranes at the free water−oil interface in the presence of differently charged surfactants and comprehensively characterized their structure and properties. Combined with computational simulations, an in situ visualization of interfacial film formation discovered the critical role of Marangoni instability induced by the surfactants via various mechanisms in structurally regulating the nanofilms. Despite their different instability-triggering mechanisms, the delicate control of the surfactants enabled the fabrication of defect-free, ultra-permselective nanofilm membranes. Our study identifies critical IP parameters that allow us to rationally design nanofilms, coatings, and membranes for target applications.
label: Autonomous Interfacial Assembly of Polymer Nanofilms via Surfactant-Regulated Marangoni Instability

question:
Is IP always self-limiting?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
This point appears to be widely agreed upon – the reaction is self-limiting. However, recent evidence shows that, while the reaction is indeed slowed down considerably as seen in practically all studies described herein, this is not necessarily an intrinsic property of the film-formation process. Rather, this can be attributed to the actual barrier posed by the forming film and, perhaps as importantly, to the availability of MPD. The second point was suggested in some earlier IP models and was illustrated by Ukrainsky and Ramon, where films with thicknesses on the order of tens of microns were fabricated in a microfluidic channel, indicating that so long as MPD is supplied to the system, the IP process continues, albeit at a slower rate.
label: Not always, depending on the MPD supplied to the system.

question:
What was the key advantage of using short chain amino-rich monomers (SCA) over conventional macro-monomers (ARM)?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
Interestingly, the high Mg2+ rejection and high Li + permeability led to the PA-g-TETA membrane to possess an extremely high SLi,Mg of all above 90 in the WMg2+/Li + range of 5:1–200:1. The SLi,Mg even reached above 130 while treating the feed with a high WMg2+/Li+ of 200. The above phenomena were different from the reported results that the Mg2+ rejection was obviously decreased with the increase in WMg2+/Li+ in literature. The surprising results linked to the uniformity of charge distribution on the surface of TETA grafted PA membrane, which may be explained as follows and illustrated from the schematic diagram in Fig. 8. It was known that Mg2+ and Li+ in mixed salt system easily existed in the form of ion clusters of Mg2+/Li+/nCl⋅H2O. In high WMg2+/Li+ feed, free Mg2+ ions would markedly increase and the large-sized Mg2+/Li+/nCl⋅H2O ion clusters would reduce. For the PA membrane grafted with ARM monomers (PEI600), the big steric energy among ARM monomers would lead to big charge gaps on the membrane surface, which could not effectively electrostatically repel the free Mg2+ even in the presence of high-density positive charges. Different from grafting ARM monomers, the grafting of SCA monomers could construct a uniform positive charge layer on the surface of PA membrane to form small positively charged gaps, which effectively rejected the free Mg2+ even in high WMg2+/Li+ feed to obtain a high separation factor (SLi,Mg).
label: More uniform charge distribution

Why is Li+/Mg2+ separation from salt lake brine challenging?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
Currently, Li+ resources mainly originate from salt lake brine which is over 70% of its general reserves. How did the addition of chitosan affect the thermal stability of the membranes?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
The membranes comprising cellulose–chitosan blends at varying weight ratios were successfully prepared using DMSO–[Bmim][OAc] as a cosolvent mixture. Based on the TGA results (Fig. 2a), the membranes with a higher chitosan content were generally more thermally stable than the pristine cellulose membrane M5, as demonstrated by the higher decomposition temperature of the blend membranes (~350 ℃) compared with M5 (300 ℃). The release of adsorbed water from the atmosphere was more pronounced in M5 because the first step of the weight loss curve below 150 ◦C was steeper than those for the other membranes. The improved thermal stability of the membranes fabricated using the cellulose–chitosan blends may be attributed to the entanglement of chitosan between the cellulose chains. The nanoindentation test revealed the hardening of the blend membranes after increasing the chitosan content (Fig. 2b). Improving the membrane hardness affords enhanced mechanical properties, beneficial for filtration applications.
label: Chitosan increased thermal stability by forming entanglements with cellulose chains.

question:
How does SDS form a PA membrane with a uniform pore size distribution？
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
More importantly, the SDS-facilitated trans-interface transport of PIP also results in spatially more uniform diffusion of PIP across the interface, which is essential for the formation of a PA membrane with a uniform pore size distribution. The relationship between energy barrier and flux uniformity can be semi-quantitatively illustrated by Monte Carlo (MC) simulations of the trans-interface transport of a group of particles with their kinetic energy following a Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution at a specific temperature. The underlying assumption is that, if the energy state of a particle exceeds a given energy barrier for trans-interface diffusion, that specific particle can successfully cross the interface. With this assumption, MC simulations of trans-interface diffusion events for 1000 particles across a 10 × 10 grid suggest that a lower energy barrier results in faster and more uniform flux across the interface (Fig. 3f, g). The total number of diffusion-attempts (trials) and the standard deviation of the numbers of particles passing through each grid opening decrease systematically as the energy barrier decreases (Fig. 3g), which suggests that reduced energy barrier does not only accelerate interfacial transport of PIP but also renders it more uniform. Additionally, the self-assembled SDS network at the water-hexane interface may also impose steric hindrance against the diffusion of newly formed PA fragments to water, which reduces the competing hydrolysis reaction and thereby also increases the degree of crosslinking. Therefore, both the enhancement of PIP diffusion and the suppression of undesirable hydrolysis synergistically lead to a higher degree of crosslinking (Fig. 2e) and a more homogeneous pore size distribution (Fig. 2a).
label: Reduce energy barrier across the interface.

question:
How is ultrasonic technology applied to membrane fouling control?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
When the ultrasonic intensity increases and exceeds the Blake threshold acoustic pressure, cavitation bubbles form in the liquid. The shear stress generated by the movement and collapse of these bubbles can further clean the membrane surface. Meanwhile, when the cavitation bubbles collapse, the extreme conditions inside cause the pyrolysis of water, generating hydrogen radicals (·H) and hydroxyl radicals (·OH), etc. These highly reactive radicals can react rapidly with surrounding chemical substances and are used to degrade organic pollutants in membrane fouling.
label: The energy released by the collapse of the cavitation bubble causes the water to pyrolyze and produce free radicals, which can react with surrounding chemicals.

When the ultrasonic intensity increases and exceeds the Blake threshold acoustic pressure, cavitation bubbles form in the liquid. Okay, let's break down how ultrasonic technology is used to control membrane fouling, based on the provided context:

1.  **Cavitation Bubble Formation:** Ultrasonic waves, when applied with sufficient intensity (exceeding the Blake threshold), create cavitation bubbles in the liquid near the membrane surface.

2.  **Shear Stress Cleaning:** The movement and, more importantly, the violent collapse of these cavitation bubbles generate significant shear stress. This shear stress acts as a cleaning force, dislodging foulants (the substances causing the fouling) from the membrane surface.

3.  **Radical Generation and Degradation:** The extreme conditions within the collapsing cavitation bubbles cause water molecules to break apart (pyrolysis). This process produces highly reactive free radicals, such as hydrogen radicals (·H) and hydroxyl radicals (·OH).

4.  **Foulant Degradation:** These free radicals are very reactive and readily attack organic pollutants that contribute to membrane fouling. The radicals react with and degrade these organic foulants, breaking them down into smaller, less harmful substances.

In summary, ultrasonic technology combats membrane fouling through a two-pronged approach: physical cleaning via cavitation-induced shear stress and chemical degradation of organic foulants via free radical reactions.

You can refer to the following context for your answer:
When the ultrasonic intensity increases and exceeds the Blake threshold acoustic pressure, cavitation bubbles form in the liquid. The shear stress generated by the movement and collapse of these bubbles can further clean the membrane surface. Meanwhile, when the cavitation bubbles collapse, the extreme conditions inside cause the pyrolysis of water, generating hydrogen radicals (·H) and hydroxyl radicals (·OH), etc. These highly reactive radicals can react rapidly with surrounding chemical substances and are used to degrade organic pollutants in membrane fouling.
A: Let's think step by step.

messages.content:
Okay, let's break down how ultrasonic technology is used to control membrane fouling, based on the provided context:

1.  **Cavitation Bubble Formation:** Ultrasonic waves, when applied with sufficient intensity (exceeding the Blake threshold), create cavitation bubbles in the liquid near the membrane surface.

2.  **Shear Stress Cleaning:** The movement and, more importantly, the violent collapse of these cavitation bubbles generate significant shear stress. This shear stress acts as a cleaning force, dislodging foulants (the substances causing the fouling) from the membrane surface.

3.  **Radical Generation and Degradation:** The extreme conditions within the collapsing cavitation bubbles cause water molecules to break apart (pyrolysis). This process produces highly reactive free radicals, such as hydrogen radicals (·H) and hydroxyl radicals (·OH).

4.  **Foulant Degradation:** These free radicals are very reactive and readily attack organic pollutants that contribute to membrane fouling. The radicals react with and degrade these organic foulants, breaking them down into smaller, less harmful substances.

In summary, ultrasonic technology combats membrane fouling through a two-pronged approach: physical cleaning via cavitation-induced shear stress and chemical degradation of organic foulants via free radical reactions.

Ultrasonic technology controls membrane fouling through two main mechanisms:

1.  **Physical Cleaning:** High-intensity ultrasound generates cavitation bubbles. The collapse of these bubbles creates shear stress that dislodges foulants from the membrane surface.
2.  **Chemical Degradation:** Cavitation bubble collapse also produces highly reactive free radicals (like ·H and ·OH) that degrade organic pollutants contributing to fouling.

question:
Please generate a title for this article based on the abstract.
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
An approximate analytical model of film formation by interfacial polycondensation is presented. The analysis requires knowledge of a minimal set of certain kinetic parameters (monomer diffusivities and reaction rate constants) and reaction conditions (monomer concentrations and thickness of the unstirred layer). The process proceeds as a succession of two or three markedly different kinetic regimes. Each regime (insipient film formation, slowdown, and diffusion-limited growth) sets a different pattern of local polymer accumulation, with important implications for the structure of the emerging film. At the incipient stage, a loose polymer film begins to emerge in a fixed narrow region inside the boundary layer, followed by gradual densification of the middle part of the film. A condition for film formation is thus formulated on the basis of our analysis. The model predicts that two different scenarios are possible, which depend on the permeability of the polymer: films with a low permeability to both monomers pass through an abrupt slowdown of film growth, whereas permeable films undergo a smooth transition between the incipient film formation and diffusion-limited regimes. The model incorporates the highly important effects of the accumulation of reactive end groups and the decrease of monomer diffusion with the polymer concentration on the kinetics of the process and film characteristics. In addition, the validity of the utilized mean-field approach is analyzed, and the analysis suggests a direct correlation between the roughness and the thickness of the film. The results are in good agreement with an earlier numerical study and the direct structural studies of polyamide membrane films.
label: Kinetics of Film Formation by Interfacial Polycondensation

question:
According to the model, what determines the thickness of the incipient film?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
We recently reported a theoretical study of interfacial polymerization that resolves this contradiction.18 Our model does not make any postulations as to the structure of the film during the process. Instead, it attempts to explicitly obtain this structure by numerical solution of diffusion and reaction equations. The model reveals that the stage of diffusion-limited growth is preceded by a very different kinetic regimesincipient film formationsthat, in some cases, may shape the final structure and morphology of the film. The important points may be summarized as follows:18,19 (1) The model predicts rapid formation of a film of finite thickness, followed by an abrupt slowdown of the interfacial polymerization process. (2) The thickness of the incipient film decreases slowly with a decrease in concentration of either of the monomers. (3) Both the reactivity of the monomer and thickness of the boundary diffusion layer (i.e., hydrodynamic conditions) affect the film thickness. (4) The polymer film possesses a dense core (the actual barrier) hidden inside a looser polymer structure. (5) The dense core separates the film into two distinct regions, in each of which one type of monomer and end group is in large excess over the other. The latter two conclusions are in remarkable agreement with direct microscopic observation of actual polyamide films constituting reverse osmosis or nanofiltration membranes (see Figure 1).
label: Monomer diffusivities and reaction rate constants

question:
What is the critical condition for film formation by interfacial polymerization?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
It has been long known that a fast reaction rate (large k) is necessary for the formation of a film at an interface. Using the abovegiven analysis, we can quantify this statement. It is clear that a film can be formed only if the thickness of the incipient reaction zone (δ0) does not exceed the thickness of the unstirred boundary layer (L). If this condition is not fulfilled, a significant portion of the polymer will form outside the unstirred layer and will travel away from the interface by convection before its molecular weight significantly increases. Ultimately, the polymer will be evenly distributed in the bulk solution, and homogeneous bulk polymerization will thus occur.
label: Reaction rate constant exceeding a threshold value.

Okay, let's break down the critical condition for film formation in interfacial polymerization based on the provided context.

The key idea is that a film forms *at the interface* if the polymerization reaction is localized enough. This localization is determined by the competition between the reaction zone thickness (δ0) and the unstirred boundary layer thickness (L).

Here's the breakdown:

1.  **Reaction Zone Thickness (δ0):** This represents the region where the polymerization reaction is actively occurring. A smaller δ0 means the reaction is more confined to the interface.

2.  **Unstirred Boundary Layer Thickness (L):** This is the region near the interface where mixing is limited. It essentially defines the zone where the polymer has a chance to stay near the interface long enough to form a film.

3.  **The Critical Condition:** The context states that a film can only form if the thickness of the incipient reaction zone (δ0) does not exceed the thickness of the unstirred boundary layer (L).

    *   **δ0 ≤ L:** This is the critical condition. If the reaction zone is contained within the unstirred layer, the polymer stays near the interface, its molecular weight increases, and a film forms.

    *   **δ0 > L:** If the reaction zone extends beyond the unstirred layer, the polymer forms outside this layer and is carried away by convection. This leads to homogeneous bulk polymerization instead of film formation.

Therefore, the critical condition for film formation by interfacial polymerization is that the thickness of the reaction zone (δ0) must be less than or equal to the thickness of the unstirred boundary layer (L). In other words:

**δ0 ≤ L**

question:
What is the proposed mechanism for achieving ultrathin nanofilms with Janus substrates?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
The reaction kinetics under varying total diamine monomer amounts were investigated by in situ monitoring of monomer  consumption to reveal the underlying regulating mechanisms by the hydrophilic layer thickness (Fig. 3 and Figs. S8 and S9). The absorbance of a charge–transfer complex formed by piperazine and alizarin red at 520 nm linearly increases with the piperazine concentration [15]. Thus, the piperazine consumption can be determined by the absorbance change during interfacial polymerization. A real-time mode was used to monitor the concentration evolution near the reaction interface (Fig. 3A and B). To simulate the role of the hydrophilic layer, the solution volume rather than the diamine concentration was changed to adjust the total monomer amount, and the reaction interface was fixed by applying a spacer for different solution volumes. As shown in Fig. 3C, the absorbance near the interface decreases more sharply with a lower piperazine amount, indicating that the piperazine concentration near the interface decreased more quickly. The reduced concentration may decrease  the diffusion rate of piperazine across the interface to the reaction zone according to Fick's law, which can slow down the formation of polyamide nanofilms. Furthermore, by calculating the monomer consumption, lower piperazine participated in the reaction with decreased total amount of piperazine under the same reaction time. This result proves that the aqueous solution volume or total monomer amount control provides an effective way to adjust the reaction kinetics, polymerization window, and polyamide growth. On the other hand, the reaction kinetics can also be reflected by the consumption rate of trimesoyl chloride, which can be obtained by in situ monitoring its concentration change according to the positive linear relationship between the concentration and the absorbance peak of the organic solution at 290 nm (Figs. S8 and S9). Lower trimesoyl chloride was consumed with decreased total amount of piperazine under the same reaction time, indicating that the participation of trimesoyl chloride in the reaction can also be controlled. These results mean that the reaction between the two monomers can be confined remarkably by limiting the total amount of the diamine monomer solution, which accounts for the reduced thickness of polyamide nanofilms (Fig. 2). According to the monitoring of the reaction kinetics of interfacial polymerization, the regulation mechanism is proposed (Fig. 3D). At the initial stage of the reaction, a high local piperazine concentration can promote the reaction between piperazine and trimesoyl chloride to form an integral nanofilm. Subsequently, as the piperazine is consumed, the total piperazine amount decreases rapidly and the reaction is terminated at a relatively earlier stage of interfacial polymerization, avoiding the further growth of the nanofilm. This mechanism gives us a guideline to control the violent interfacial polymerization and regulate the structure and property of polyamide nanofilms.
label: The hydrophilic layer maintain a high concentration at the reaction interface, leading to form an integral nanofilm. And The hydrophobic layer prevents excessive monomer penetration, leading the reaction is terminated at a relatively earlier stage of interfacial polymerization.

What challenges does the conventional hydrophilic substrate pose in interfacial polymerization?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
In summary, we have developed a novel strategy to synthesize ultrathin polyamide nanofilms by virtue of Janus substrates as a confined interfacial polymerization platform to govern the reaction process. The aqueous solution of amine monomer  can be confined within the adjustable hydrophilic layer of the Janus substrate, by which the total monomer amount can be regulated for controlling the interfacial polymerization. By tuning the piperazine amount reserved within the Janus substrate at a low level, sub–5-nm polyamide nanofilms have been synthesized at a relatively high local piperazine concentration, which endows the polyamide nanofilms with an integral structure and small pore size. The water permeance has greatly elevated by more than six times when the nanofilm thickness decreases from 88.4 to 3.8 nm while keeping a competitive Na2SO4 rejection of ~96%. Such a composite membrane performs superior nanofiltration performance to most of the recently reported ones. This strategy offers a novel and practical “interfacial reactor” to regulate the interfacial polymerization process as well as the nanofilm structure by engineering the porous substrates.

question:
What role does tannic acid (TA) play in the TA@BM-Spray membrane?
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
The modifier TA, a cost-effective polyphenol derived from plants, contains catechol and galloyl groups that exhibit excellent coating ability. It can adhere to various substrate surfaces via covalent and/or noncovalent bonding, enabling the functionalization of liposomes with a hydrophilic surface and yolk-shell structure. Evidently, the spray-assisted integration of TA-encapsulated liposomes ensures uniform predeposition upon the substrate surface, guaranteeing a PA layer with an analogously crumpled and rough structural profile as observed in liposome-incorporated membranes. The introduction of TA mitigates potential non-selective defects through chemical interactions with reactive monomers and liposomes (e. g., Schiff base reaction, Michael addition, hydrogen bonding and acylation, etc.), as well as the strong adsorption ability onto the PSf substrate, as illustrated in Fig. 7b. As a compatibility promoter, TA plays a critical role in establishing a robust interfacial bridge between the liposomes and PA active layer at the molecular level. Simultaneously, as a hydrophilic enhancer, TA introduces multiple hydrophilic sites enveloping the liposomes, making them more water-contactable and contributing to the formation of a highly hydrophilic membrane surface. In conjunction with the TA@liposomes-assisted protuberances and nanovoids, which enhance membrane surface roughness and effective surface area, along with improvement in surface hydrophilicity and cross-linking degree, these structural and physicochemical features of the TA@BM-Spray membrane collectively achieve enhanced water permeance and water-salt selectivity.
label: Chemical interactions with reactive monomers and substrates reduce potential non-selective defects. Introducing hydrophilic sites helps enhance the hydrophilicity of the membrane surface.

question:
How do nanovesicles influence the morphology of the PA layer? And explain the role of nanovesicles in enhancing water permeance.
You can refer to the following context for your answer:
To comprehensively rationalize the observed separation performances, we initially reassess the design of the bioinspired SWRO membranes. Characterization results demonstrate that the nanovesicleintegrated PA selective layer differs significantly from its nanovesiclefree counterpart. Traditionally, amine monomers undergo diffusion across the aqueous phase to react with the organic monomers at the immiscible interface, forming a dense selective layer with minimal nanovoids and restricted effective surface area. This results in relatively low water permeance and moderate salt rejection. Nevertheless, the incorporation of E. coli-based liposomes via conventional blending or spray-assisted predeposition increases the diffusion rate and penetration depth of amine monomers into the organic phase. This effect is mainly owing to the creation of a broader “miscible region” at the reaction interface, driven by lower interfacial tension, which results in a PA morphology with greater protuberance and a rougher structure (Fig. 7a). In the BM-Conv and BM-spray membranes, this crumpled structure, characterized by a larger surface area and enhanced wettability, along with the lower hydrodynamic resistance from increased rear surface porosity and larger nanovoids size beneath the crumpled PA active layer, collectively facilitates the water transport of the liposomesincorporated membranes. However, the intensified polymerization process induced by the presence of liposomes due to the increased monomer supply and the local temperature rise can destabilize incipient PA oligomers, leading to a loosely cross-linked PA matrix. This contributes to higher water permeance but compromises water-salt selectivity. More importantly, the formation of additional channels and non-selective defects between the unreactive liposomes and the PA layer, as well as substrate, due to poor interfacial compatibility, further accounts for the slight decline in salt rejection observed in membranes embedded with unmodified liposomes. Despite this, the bioinspired membranes fabricated using conventional blending and spray-assisted strategies demonstrated comparable separation performance. Notably, the amount of liposomes required for the spray-assisted membrane was only 3.8 % of that needed for the blending strategy, indicating that the spraying approach allows precise control of liposome deposition and minimizes wastage of valuable additives, ensuring high utilization efficiency.
label: They reduce interfacial tension, promoting amine monomer diffusion and forming a rougher structure. This rougher structure increased surface area, and improved hydrophilicity.
